content:
The Act is titled the "United States Commission on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries Act of 2016" and establishes a commission known as the United States Commission on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The Commission is tasked with specific duties outlined in the Act. The United States Commission on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries Act of 2016 establishes a commission to investigate anti-competitive involvement of OPEC, its members, and affiliated entities in oil markets, and make recommendations to reduce adverse impacts on the United States. The Commission's duties include investigating behavior designed to disadvantage US oil producers, assessing the impact of OPEC's policies on US economic and energy security interests, and evaluating existing relationships of Federal agencies with OPEC. The United States Commission on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries Act of 2016 establishes a commission to investigate OPEC's anti-competitive actions in oil markets and recommend ways to reduce their adverse impacts on the US, including policy reforms in taxes, trade, defense, research and development, and diplomacy. SEC. 4. MEMBERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall consist of 16 members appointed by the President as follows: 4 members independently determined to be qualified, 4 members nominated by the Senate majority leader, 4 members nominated by the Speaker of the House, and 2 members from a separate list. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the President. 2 members are appointed from lists nominated by the Senate and House minority leaders, focusing on energy issues. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the President, with expertise in oil and gas exploration, production, refining, pipelines, transportation, national security, foreign policy, macroeconomics, labor, environment, logistics, shipping, tourism, consumer goods, and manufacturing. Members must be U.S. citizens and appointments should be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the President with expertise in various fields. Each member serves for the duration of the Commission, vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairman is selected by the President and is responsible for assigning duties, supervising staff, and managing funds. Meetings are generally open to the public but can be closed for specific reasons. The Commission holds open meetings where interested persons can present statements on the subject matter. Meetings are preceded by public notice in the Federal Register and minutes are kept with records of attendees and discussions. The minutes, records, and documents of Commission meetings are available for public inspection at a single location. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. SEC. 5. STAFFING AND RESOURCES. The chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed the rate for Level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is allowed to obtain necessary information from federal departments and agencies to fulfill its duties. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from federal departments and agencies, enter into contracts, and establish a science and technical advisory panel to assist in preparing its report. SEC. 6. REPORT.

The Commission must submit a report to Congress and the President within 1 year of the Act's enactment, detailing findings and recommendations on activities required by section 3. Administrative procedures for the report are exempt from certain codes.

SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 90 days after submitting the report under section 6.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2017 and 2018 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended.

SEC. 9. POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS. Within 90 days of receiving the Commission's report, the President must submit proposals to Congress based on the recommendations in the report.
